huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access. There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access. Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit. Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers. Satellite phones do work in the area. The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

The Book Cliffs mountain range is one of the more remote areas in Utah. There are no service stations for many miles. Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, and good tires with extra spares.

The Book Cliffs has a high bear population. Keep a clean camp and put your garbage in a place that is inaccessible to bears. If you do have problems with bears please report them to the DWR Northeastern Regional Office as soon as possible (435 781-9453), or call the local dispatch center (435 789-4222).
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for rain, lightning, and snow. Storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 38.9~7500 (entire Book Cliffs unit)~5500 (entire Book Cliffs unit)~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
The Book Cliffs elk herd has been stagnant for several years, biologists and researchers have been monitoring the populations age structure and pregnancy rates and we have observed alarming results - a very old elk population with extremely low pregnancy rates. This cow hunt was designed to remove some elk, hopefully some of these older cows that are abundant in the population. Older females have been documented to produce fewer calves. We are working to have a healthy and productive elk population on the Book Cliffs. To get better data on the age class of this population all successful applicants will be contacted by the DWR and given instructions to collect and submit teeth for aging harvested animals. It is very important that hunters submit teeth from harvested cows.



This is a quality elk hunt that should provide plenty of opportunities to harvest a cow elk, if you are an experienced hunter or even a novice/youth hunter. Many times I see elk during these season dates near main roads and fairly accessible areas. The cows and calves will migrate to lower elevations but most will stay along the Divide Ridge. Once the snow melts elk will be more tied to sustainable water sources. During the summer month’s elk congregate to the Divide Ridge. After the calving season you can find large herds of elk. Once the rut begins the bulls begin to herd up smaller herds of cows and the elk seem to spread out through the whole Book Cliffs Range. Some years the temperature starts to fall and causes the ponds and guzzlers to freeze. Springs and creeks will still flow, and can be good areas to hunt.

Some of the main roads/areas to focus your hunting efforts on are: Seep Ridge Road, McCook Ridge, Big Park, Bitter Creek, and the many spur ridges and valleys adjacent to the Book Cliffs Divide Road. Take careful note of the boundary with the Book Cliffs, Little Creek or Roadless area if you proceed west beyond 10 Mile Knoll on the Divide Road, this area is not included in this hunt boundary.

Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential for scouting elk in this area. There are several recovering burned areas that have produced large amounts of grass that is excellent for elk. Elk spend a lot of time in the aspen patches where there is a good understory of grass and forbs.

huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: Hunters who obtain this permit are encouraged, but not required, to submit a harvest report. Report your harvest online or by calling 1-800-221-0659.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, Willow Creek, and Nash Wash WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days. 
DWR WMA’S:  UDWR WMAs is limited to 14 days at one location.  On the Willow Creek WMA, camping is not allowed.  In the parcels that can be accessed by county roads there is no camping allowed.  Camping is only allowed in the parcels where the roads are closed, like Meadow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Seep Ridge Road (UT 88) and the Bonanza Highway/Atchee Ridge Road (UT 45) from the North, Hay Canyon from I-70 on the South
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads. There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA. The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.

The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access. There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads. The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.

There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs. The Kings Well Rd starts at the Seep Ridge Rd on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Rd on the east side. The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Rd and goes through the bottom of Sweet Water, top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek, and to Big Park. It is a great road to locate wildlife during this time of year.

Interstate 70 will provide access to most of the drainages on the south side of the Book Cliffs. Wildlife are found often found in these canyons. Major canyons and access points include Thompson/Sego Canyon, Nash Wash, Cottonwood Canyon, Hay/Middle/East Canyons, and Bryson Canyon. There are roads that will take you to the top of the Book Cliffs only in Sego Canyon, Hay Canyon, East Canyon, and Bitter Creek. The remainder of the roads dead end a short way up the canyons.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands.  There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the White River; west along this river to the Green River; south along this river to Swasey’s Boat Ramp and the Hastings Road; south on this road to SR-19; south and east on SR-19 to Exit 164 on 1-70 near the town of Green River; east on I-70 to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the White River. EXCLUDES THE BOOK CLIFFS, LITTLE CREEK ROADLESS UNIT. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Moab, Price, Seep Ridge, Vernal, Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453 or the Price office, 435-613-3700. EXCLUDES Book Cliffs, Little Creek Roadless Unit as follows: Book Cliffs, Little Creek Roadless Grand County--Boundary begins at Steer Ridge road and Ten Mile Knoll; southwest along Diamond Ridge and the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide) to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation boundary (Hells Hole/head of Sego Canyon); north along this boundary (west side of West Willow Creek) to the Wildlife Management Area/Ute Tribe Fence at the confluence of East and West Willow Creek; northeast to the west fork of the Steer Ridge road (NW 1/4 Sec 7, T17 S R 21 E); south and east along the Steer Ridge road (atop the drainage divide) to Ten Mile Knoll. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
